facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 128 of 1962 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 128 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated January 30, 1962, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 429 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 30, 1962, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 429 of 1960.

facts.text: Certificate for appeal granted by the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the Calcutta High Court.

facts.text: Appellant hired a Westinghouse motor from the Modern Electrical Works on April 4, 1958, on rent of Rs. 40 per month.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant hired a westing house, C. motor from the Modem Electrical Works  hereinafter referred to as the Works  on April 4, 1958 on a rent of Rs. 40 per month.

facts.text: Hiring period was to last for at least three months.

anchor.surface_text: The hiring period was to last for at least three months

facts.text: Agreement that if motor or parts lost or damaged by appellant, he would pay full cost.

anchor.surface_text: and it was agreed that if the motor or parts thereof were lost or damaged by the appellant, he would be bound to pay the whole companyt of the motor and the parts.

facts.text: Motor remained in use of appellant and hire-charges paid from April 1958 to January 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The motor remained in the use of the appellant and hire-charges were paid by him from April 1958 to January 1959.

facts.text: Thereafter no hire-charges were paid.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter it is said that numberhire-charges were paid.

facts.text: On June 8, 1959, appellant wrote a letter to the Works claiming purchase of motor for Rs. 600 on condition of trial for three months.

anchor.surface_text: On June 8, 1959, the appellant wrote a letter to the Works in which he said that he had purchased the motor in question for Rs. 600 on companydition that the same would be tried for three months,

facts.text: Appellant claimed in letter that if satisfactory, money paid and purchase completed; if not, pay three months hire and return motor.

anchor.surface_text: and if it was found satisfactory the money would be paid and the purchase companypleted. The letter also stated that the agreement was that if the motor was number found satisfactory,

facts.text: Appellant stated in letter that Works paid Rs. 620 in all and purchase completed, requested slip confirming sale.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant would pay three months hire at Rs. 40 per month and the motor would be returned thereafter. Finally, the appellant said in the letter that the Works had been paid Rs. 620 in all

facts.text: On June 15, 1959, Works replied denying the agreement alleged by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On June 15, 1959, the Works sent a reply to the appellant denying that any such agreement as was alleged by the appellant had been made.

facts.text: Works denied Rs. 620 paid, said only Rs. 400 paid, Rs. 200 due for Feb to June 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It was also denied that Rs. 620 had been paid, and therefore the purchase was companyplete. Finally it was said that the appellant had only paid Rs. 400 and Rs. 200 were still due

facts.text: Appellant replied to Works' letter reiterating his stand and details of Rs. 620 payment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant replied to this letter in which he reiterated his stand taken in the earlier letter and gave details of how the payment of Rs. 620 had been made.

facts.text: Works filed complaint through Mohd. Ayub on July 1, 1959, alleging criminal breach of trust under s. 406 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Works filed a companyplaint through its servant Mohd. Ayub on July 1, 1959 in which after stating its case it urged that the appellant had companymitted criminal breach

facts.text: Presidency Magistrate 9th Court, Calcutta summoned appellant.

facts.text: Presidency Magistrate 9th Court discharged appellant after some prosecution evidence, holding no satisfactory evidence of dishonest misappropriation, dispute civil.

anchor.surface_text: and after taking some evidence for the prosecution, the Magistrate discharged the appellant holding that there was numbersatisfactory evidence of dishonest misappropriation or companyversion of the motor

facts.text: Mohd. Ayub filed revision to Calcutta High Court against discharge.

anchor.surface_text: by the appellant to his own use and that the dispute between the parties was essentially of a civil nature. Mohd. Ayub then went in revision to the High Court.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court set aside discharge order and directed further enquiry by another Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court set aside the order of discharge and directed further enquiry in the matter by another Magistrate.

facts.text: Third Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta acquitted appellant, finding dispute on nature of transaction, no dishonest intention.

facts.text: It is not in dispute that the motor was entrusted to the appellant by the Works for his use.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute between the parties that the motor was entrusted to the appellant by the Works for his use.

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for criminal breach of trust

anchor.surface_text: defined in s. 405 of the Indian Penal Code and punishable under S. 406 thereof.

concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of criminal breach of trust

anchor.surface_text: Now s. 405 runs as follows - Whoever, being in any manner entrusted with property, or with any dominion over property, dishonestly mis- appropriates or converts to his own use that property, or dishonestly uses or disposes of that property in violation of any direction of law prescribing the mode in which such trust is to be discharged, or of any legal contract, express or implied, which he has made touching the discharge of such trust, or wilfully suffers any other person so to do, commits criminal breach of trust. It may be accepted that the appellant was entrusted with the motor by virtue of the agreement between him and the Works, the terms of which are seriously in dispute.

concepts.interpretation: Entrustment admitted but no dishonest misappropriation, conversion, use or disposal in violation of legal contract as there was no change in the use of the motor or disposal to a third party; the letter merely asserts a civil claim over the terms of entrustment without altering possession or use.

anchor.surface_text: The question however is whether the appellant dishonestly misappropriated or converted to his own use that motor. On the facts in the present case the motor was handed over to the appellant for his use even according to the case of the Works.

issues.text: whether this entrustment was merely by way of hire or on the basis of an agreement that the appellant would purchase the motor if he found it satisfactory after trying it for three months

anchor.surface_text: The dispute was whether this entrustment was merely by way of hire (which was the case of the Works) or, as was the case of the appellant, was on the basis of an agreement between the parties that the appellant would purchase the motor if he found it satisfactory after trying it for three months and pay Rs. 600 as the price and that he would return it if he found it unsatisfactory during this period of three months and pay Rs. 40 each month as hire for that period.

holdings.text: The real dispute between the parties therefore was as to the nature of the agreement between them when the motor was entrusted to the appellant in April 1958. That dispute was clearly of a civil nature.

anchor.surface_text: The real dispute between the parties therefore was as to the nature of the agreement between them when the motor was entrusted to the appellant in April 1958. That dispute was clearly of a civil

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute over terms of entrustment is contractual, appropriately resolved in civil proceedings rather than criminal.

holdings.text: it cannot be said that merely by writing that letter of June 8, the appellant dealt with the motor in such manner as would amount to its misappropriation or conversion to his own use by him.

anchor.surface_text: it cannot be said that merely by writing that letter of June 8, the appellant dealt with the motor in such manner as would amount to its misappropriation or conversion to his own use by him. Clearly

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of change in possession or use of motor; continued permitted use before and after letter.

holdings.text: There is however nothing to show that by writing the letter of June 8 the appellant used the motor in violation of any legal contract, express or implied, which he had made with respect to it for use of the motor was the same before the letter as well as after it. Nor can it be said that the appellant had disposed of the motor in violation of any legal contract which he had made with respect thereto for it is not the case of the Works that the appellant had parted with the possession of the motor to somebody else.

anchor.surface_text: There is however nothing to show that by writing the letter of June 8 the appellant used the motor in violation of any legal contract, express or implied, which he had made with respect to it for use

holdings.reasoning_summary: Use of motor unchanged by letter; no disposal or transfer to third party evidenced.

holdings.text: Clearly s. 405 contemplates something being done with respect to the property which would indicate either misappropriation or conversion or its use or disposal in violation of the contract, express or implied. But where, as in the present case, nothing was done with respect to the use of the property which was not in accordance with the hiring agreement between the parties, it cannot be said that there was misappropriation or conversion of the property or its use or disposal in violation of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly s. 405 contemplates something being done with respect to the property which would indicate either misappropriation or conversion or its use or disposal in violation of the contract, express or

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language requires affirmative act altering property dealing; mere claim assertion insufficient.

holdings.text: All that we emphasise is that the letter of June 8 merely raises a dispute of civil nature between the parties and there is no question of any criminal breach of trust with respect to the motor on the basis of that letter.

anchor.surface_text: All that we emphasise is that the letter of June 8 merely raises a dispute of civil nature between the parties and there is no question of any criminal breach of trust with respect to the motor on

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter asserts disputed ownership claim without violating entrustment terms through action.

holdings.text: We are not expressing any opinion as to the correctness of the case either of the appellant or of the Works in this behalf.

anchor.surface_text: We are not expressing any opinion as to the correctness of the case either of the appellant or of the Works in this behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual contract terms unnecessary to resolve for determining absence of criminal elements.

holdings.text: In this view of the matter we allow the appeal, set aside the conviction of the appellant and order his acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter we allow the appeal, set aside the conviction of the appellant and order his acquittal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of s.405 elements precludes liability under s.406 IPC; reverses lower court conviction.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter we allow the appeal, set aside the conviction of the appellant and order his acquittal. The fine, if paid.
